elements.title: Eatoniella mortoni (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the New Zealand mollusc Eatoniella mortoni (pictured) can thrive in extreme carbon dioxide-rich environments, making it a subject for the study of ocean acidification?

elements.title: save Abu Simbel, Philae and many other temples (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the global coalition to save Abu Simbel, Philae and many other temples led to the creation of the modern list of World Heritage Sites?

elements.title: spatial inequality (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that spatial inequality refers to the unequal distribution of income and resources across geographical regions?

elements.title: Motilla del Azuer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that an interdisciplinary study concluded that the Motilla del Azuer was built during the 4.2-kiloyear BP aridification event, in a long period of severe drought?

elements.title: its own power plant (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Grumman Aerospace built its own power plant because it was cheaper than buying electricity from utilities?

elements.title: MoSys (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that academics called MoSys's 1T-SRAM a misnomer with "a catchy name"?

elements.title: a song that criticizes abusive men in power (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that to protest against the overturning of Roe v. Wade, Billie Eilish performed a song that criticizes abusive men in power?

elements.title: María Urquides (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that María Urquides was the "Mother of Bilingual Education"?
